There were innumerable bodhisattvas, all of whom were inconceivable, universally endowed with skillful means, roaming in the Buddha's treasury, surpassing the practices of MÄra, equal to the sands of the Ganges in their vast compassion and the six perfections, rescuing beings in a timely manner and bringing them peace, far abandoning fame and teaching, such as AvalokiteÅ›vara, Maitreya, and others who were foremost.

Then the TathÄgata entered the samÄdhi of divine stillness, transformation, and realization, universally responding to the buddha-realms of the sands of the Ganges. In front of the Buddha's seat, there suddenly appeared a lotus flower seat that spontaneously emerged from the ground. The pure fragrance of the flower illuminated the ten directions. On each of the flower's thousand petals, there was a transformed bodhisattva standing in attendance, mysteriously dwelling in the sky. Each of them prostrated with their five limbs and circumambulated to the right seven times. They respectfully stood in front and together exclaimed in a great voice, Never before has there been such a thing!
Yes, World-Honored One!

We ourselves, in our own lands, see a spiritual auspicious tree that has transformed. When the tree first appears, its light illuminates the worlds of the Buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges. The tree emits a great sound, its voice pure, clear, elegant, compassionate, and harmonious, penetrating the minds of the multitude. Those who hear it rejoice and attain perfect equality, giving rise to the practices of the Great Vehicle and fulfilling the six pÄramitÄs and the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, completing all the Buddha's work.
At that time, in the worlds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, each TathÄgata sent a Bodhisattva to proclaim the Way and glorify the Great Vehicle, telling the Bodhisattvas:

You should go from this Buddha land, across lands as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, to a Buddha land called Saha (meaning 'enduring world'), where the Buddha named ÅšÄkyamuni TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, uses the Dharma, spiritual powers, and teachings to carry out the Buddha's work.
Each TathÄgata held a lotus flower with a thousand petals and gave it to the Bodhisattva, saying:

You should convey my respects to him, saying that I rejoice that the virtuous one has accomplished his mission and fulfilled his aspirations, and that he has fully embodied the essence of the Way. He has descended into the five turbidities to bear the heavy responsibility for the multitude, surpassing Maitreya and taking precedence over him. With his vast compassion and the six perfections, he universally delivers all beings. I hope that he is well and that the Way and the teachings are always victorious. I now offer these flowers as a Dharma offering, wishing that all may gather in the Way-place.

Those bodhisattvas, receiving the Buddha's majestic spiritual power, suddenly disappeared from their lands, and entered the samÄdhi of tranquil stillness, the samÄdhi of contemplation. In an instant, they all arrived in the SahÄ world, each leaving their seats and standing there with dignity and respect. They bowed to the holy transformation, prostrating with their five bodies to the ground, then circumambulated seven times and returned to their original positions. Their spiritual feet were profoundly still, their deportment was solemn, and their Dharma robes were properly arranged. They all spoke in loud voices, addressing the Buddha, saying:

Our World-Honored One, the TathÄgata of our land, pays homage to you countless times. We rejoice that you have accomplished your goals, perfected the essence of the Way, and descended into the five turbidities to take on the heavy responsibility for the sake of many. You surpassed Maitreya and became the first, widely practicing the six pÄramitÄs of compassion to universally save all beings. Your daily life is light and comfortable, and the Way's teachings are always victorious.
Now we offer these flowers to form a Dharma offering, wishing to universally gather all at the Way's site.
The Buddha said:
Virtuous ones!

Rejoicing in the tireless wise teachings of those TathÄgatas, the samÄdhi is unobstructed, the Dharma body is empty and pure, and the wisdom illumination is widely complete. This and that are equally one, and the praise of what is heard brings immeasurable joy.

At that time, TathÄgata Nengren received the flowers with his hands, smiled joyfully, and light emerged from his mouth, illuminating the worlds of the Buddhas in the ten directions, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River. He then scattered the flowers equally to the Buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, and the light also penetrated the worlds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River. Each sentient being was graced by the Buddha's compassionate light and all attained the wisdom to understand their past lives. They illuminated the hells and the three evil destinies and the eight difficulties, as well as the heavens and the human realm, all being graced by the compassionate light and attaining liberation. Hundreds of thousands of sentient beings all gave rise to the intention of the unsurpassed true path.
The light then returned, circled around the Buddha's body three times, and disappeared into the crown of his head.

At that time, the Buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River all saw each other through their spiritual powers. The majestic spiritual powers of the Buddhas universally enabled all sentient beings to see the Buddha. After the manifestation of the transformation was complete, everything returned to normal.
At that time, there was a bodhisattva in the assembly named Xianru, who then praised in verse in front of the Buddha:
Wonderful indeed is the great sage's transformation, having compassion for the multitude of beings,
From countless eons, accumulating meritorious practices.
For each meritorious practice, there are several hundred thousand,
One hundred merits form one characteristic, I wish to pay homage to the Honored One of the three times.
Wonderful indeed is the great sage's transformation, his benevolence and wisdom are boundless,
The Way's teachings are pure and noble, the ÅšÄkya Master, the Heaven of Heavens.
Great wisdom is lofty and unsurpassed, the Dharma boat ferries the multitude of beings,
The sage's wisdom is pure and immeasurable, I wish to pay homage to the unsurpassed Honored One.
Wonderful indeed is the great sage's transformation, the light of compassion moistens the Ganges sands,
Ignorance and darkness have all been removed, confusion and enlightenment reverse turbidity and clarity.
Gracious blessings accord with the season's appropriateness, skillful means connect with the multitude of beings,
The Dharma bridge ferries all, I wish to pay homage to the Honored One of the three realms.
Thereupon, the sage teacher said to the virtuous Confucian scholar:
The buddhas' Dharma smiles has three causes and conditions.
What are the three?

The cognition of omniscience is profound, subtle, and far-reaching, illuminating the three times and penetrating to the source of sentient beings. Those who aspire to the three vehicles each have their fundamental practices and complete faith. Some bodhisattvas aspire to vast vows, donning the great armor of virtue and taking on the heavy responsibility for the sake of the many. They cut off their aspirations and become bridges for the world, exclusively promoting the six perfections without abandoning any. Abiding on the path, they gradually develop courageous and vigorous progress, practicing giving without characteristics, precepts, patience, and practice, and maintaining meditation without confusion, with the clear and bright wisdom of cognition heading towards irreversibility.
This, wise ones!
The Buddha's eye sees each and every one receiving the prediction;
Not only is the prediction given by one buddha, but all the buddhas in the present of the ten directions also give the prediction.
This is the first cause and condition.
Furthermore, wise ones!

If there is a bodhisattva who is about to become a Buddha, having accumulated merits and virtues and fully endowed with sagely wisdom, making offerings to innumerable Buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, receiving a prediction from each one, with the predictions mutually illuminating, illuminating and purifying the Buddha-lands, equally nurturing sentient beings, all practicing the same way, inviting the Buddhas and sages, the great benevolent ones, to cross the four torrents, exhausting the ocean of the six desires and drying up the twelve entrances, entering the five paths and purifying the five eyes, concentrating the spirit in profound tranquility and dwelling in the Tuá¹£ita Palace, gathering the bodhisattvas, the enlightened ones and the righteous ones, purifying the practices of the three realms and expounding the irreversible wheel.

The Buddhas of the ten directions, in the assemblies of the four groups, all together praise such a bodhisattva, extolling his virtues, saying that he will soon descend and become a Buddha, and the sentient beings of the ten directions will all attain liberation.

Furthermore, virtuous man!
If there is a bodhisattva who, having completed his heavenly lifespan in the Tuá¹£ita Palace, is about to descend and take birth, he will then enter the final samÄdhi of extensive manifestation.

The gods of the Pure Abode universally observe the trichiliocosm, the vast countries and cities, and the gentle beings, the ká¹£atriyas, brahmins, elders, and householders. These are the three causes and conditions.

The bodhisattvas who come here are all people who were originally related to the TathÄgata. The Four Heavenly Kings and below serve what is appropriate. They go to the Bodhi tree and recall the method of leaving home of the Buddhas of the past. The knife had not yet approached the hair when it suddenly fell off by itself, and the flesh-crown naturally became apparent.
The Bodhisattva thought:
When the Buddhas of the past left the household life and cut their hair, they should have had the Dharma robes.
As soon as he had this thought, a god from the Pure Abode took a heavenly robe from the desire realm and offered it to the Bodhisattva, saying:

The reason for sitting upright for six years is to fulfill past causes and conditions. The evidence of precepts will appear in the last night of the sixth year.

The mind is in tranquil seclusion, receiving the Dharma in mountains and marshes. The spirit is true, the conduct is far-reaching, upholding the precepts and practicing the Way. Not sparing
one's life, abandoning one's body, being equal to myriad things, not seeking profit or support, guarding emptiness and practicing tranquility,

Pleasure, non-pleasure, neither pleasure nor non-pleasure, the four elements are pure, pure original abode.

Mind, thought, and consciousness, the seven dharmas, the seven dharmas are pure, pure orientation, mind without mind, not minding the mind, intention without intention, not intending the intention, consciousness without consciousness, not non-consciousness, not cognizing consciousness, not mental consciousness, combined into one.

By knowing one and eliminating one, not moving within one, the original ground of emptiness, the original pure orientation, abandoning fame, abandoning all entrances, having no lineage, not following the crowd, far from punitive

, no body, no offense, no speech, no mind, no thoughts, no worldly affairs,
No conceptual thoughts, no conditioned causes, no dwelling, no precepts,

The precept of no defilement and no attachment means no anger, no resentment, peaceful and pure, following the path to liberation.

The bodhisattva sage, first sitting under the tree, initially realizing the precepts, abandoning the root of suffering and desire, letting go of scattered thoughts, no thought of arising, no thought of movement, no subtle thought, no thought of self, no thought of others, no thought of the middle.

No thought of this and that, no thought of inside and outside, no thought of the path, no thought of the secular, no thought of extinction, extinction has no thought, no thought of no thought, no thought of no no thought, no thought of ending and no ending.
Thus, sage!
The bodhisattva sitting under the tree establishes the realization of the original 1,800 precepts.

As soon as this number was completed, the vajra seat suddenly split open from the ground and emerged, causing the sixth demon palace to greatly shake, and the gods of the three realms were uneasy in their original positions, all coming down together to the bejeweled tree to attend to what was necessary.
In the worlds of the Ganges, there was suddenly a great sound, and within the great sound it was said:
The Bodhisattva sitting under the tree will attain enlightenment tonight.
All beings heard it and saw it.
Thus, O virtuous one!

The three months of summer have passed and the end of the year has arrived. On the fourteenth night of the Posadha, when the stars appear, I will only order Ananda to strike the ghanta and spread the grass mat. I will only perform the Posadha together with Ananda.
At that time, the son of the Pure Abode Heaven in the sky said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Now the assembly of monks has dispersed. Why does the Buddha now perform the Posadha alone?
The Buddha told the son of heaven:

When I left home, you were the witness. When I went to the Bodhi tree, you were the witness again. Now when I perform the Posadha, you are the witness again. In Jambudvipa, I have gone around the three thousand worlds, and the Tathagata has accomplished the knowledge of all modes.
From the time I attained Buddhahood until my nirvana, you have been the three witnesses, and the essence is complete.
You should know, son of heaven!

The Tathagata's path wisdom and spiritual powers can alone traverse the three realms, and he still needs witnesses. How much more so for all those who practice the path, who cannot be without a teacher?
He also told the Pure Abodes:

In the final age, many people aspire to purity and clarity, their resolve for the Way is sincere and bright, they do not enjoy worldly affairs and dwell in mountain forests. If they truly have a firm resolve to leave home,
